Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2020
Award.AbstractNarration: This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2020, Integrative Research Investigating the Rules of Life Governing Interactions Between Genomes, Environment and Phenotypes. The fellowship supports research and training of the Fellow that will contribute to the area of Rules of Life in innovative ways. The process by which new species form (speciation) has long been of interest to evolutionary biologists. Though species boundaries have been documented and revised across the tree of life, this has not led to a broad understanding of speciation. In part, this shortcoming is a function of the approaches used in taxonomic research. Most available methods for uncovering species boundaries using genetic data alone ignore factors that could lend insight into speciation, while methods for combining genetic, phenotypic (trait), and ecological data rely too heavily on concordance across datatypes. The Fellowâ€™s work will develop conceptual models that link process to pattern and allow more meaningful integration across datatypes. These conceptual speciation models will be used to develop and test predictions in taildropper slugs (Genus Prophysaon). This work will provide unprecedented insight into speciation in Prophysaon, and will develop a general framework for process-based studies of species limits in non-model systems. The proposed work will also lead to the publication of a reference genome, the development of a machine-learning approach for testing predictions in genomic data, several training opportunities for undergraduate researchers, and increased taxonomic knowledge in an understudied group.<br/><br/>The Fellow will use three approaches to distinguish among factors driving speciation in Prophysaon: 1) tests of the influence of neutral and selective processes on DNA sequence variation between species, 2) tests of ecological divergence between species, and 3) tests of reproductive isolation between species. The Fellow will use genomic and transcriptomic data, machine learning, electron microscopy, geometric morphometrics, behavioral trials, and metabarcoding of gut contents to test predictions. The Fellow will actively recruit undergraduate researchers from underrepresented groups through established programs at Indiana University to collaborate on the proposed work.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

This project aimed to investigate the processes driving speciation in taildropper slugs (Genus Prophysaon) and to develop methods for investigating evolutionary processes in non-model systems. In the course of this project, the PI investigated the data and models used to study species' relationships. The PI used insights from these investigations to make robust inferences about the evolutionary history of taildropper slugs.

Typically, orthologs, or genes related through speciation events, are used to infer species relationships, while paralogs, or genes related through duplication events, are filtered from phylogenetic datasets. This can drastically limit the amount of data available, particularly in non-model systems. The PI used theoretical investigations, simulation studies, and empirical investigations to demonstrate that paralogs can be effectively used for phylogenetic inference, and that using paralogs can vastly expand the amount of data available.

Based on these findings, the fellow used transcriptomes and several methods for including or filtering paralogs to infer the phylogenetic relationships among species of taildropper slugs. The placement of the blue-grey taildropper slug (Prophysaon coeruleum) conflicts with taxonomic classifications based on morphology. The PI also discovered two phenotypically distinct populations, and transcripomic data revelaed these populations to be genetically distinct lineages belonging to the Prophysaon andersoni species group. Thus, this work suggests the need for taxonomic revision in Prophysaon. 

The PI was also interested in understanding whether gene flow between species played a role in the evolutionary history of taildropper slugs. Although we know that selection impacts large portions of most species' genomes, most methods for inferring gene flow ignore selection. The PI investigated whether several methods used to infer gene flow between populations and species were accurate in the presence of selection. The PI found that selection led to false inferences of migration using several popular methods, suggesting that caution is warranted when interpreting the results of such approaches. Using other approaches that should be robust to selection, the PI found support for gene flow having played a role in the diversification of taildropper slugs.

Finally, the PI investigated a new approach to studying morphological variation in taildropper slugs. Intraspecific variation in color and size is common in taildropper slugs, complicating the use of morphological data. The PI used Scanning Electron Microscopy to image the radulae (i.e. dentition) of these slugs. By using geometric morphometrics, the PI was able to detect phenotypic differences between closely-related species. Since radulae are used in feeding, differences in radulae may reflect differences in the ecological niches of taildropper slugs.

This project produced a well-supported phylogeny of taildropper slugs, and found evidence of gene flow between species of Prophysaon. Additionally, the project uncovered undescribed genetic and morphological diversity in taildropper slugs, and found phenotypic differences between closely related species in an ecologically important trait.


Broader Impacts

This project vastly expanded the amount of phenotypic and transcripomic data available for taildropper slugs. Further, these data resulted in the discovery of two phenotypically and genetically distinct populations of Prophysaon from the Olympic Peninsula and Oregon. Knowledge of this previously unknown diversity is essential to proper management of this group, and future work will consider whether these populations warrant elevation to species status.

During this project, the PI mentored an undergraduate researcher through the Indiana University Center for Women in Technology research program. This program focuses on mentoring freshman and sophomore undergraduate women, and the undergraduate researcher presented her work on phylogenetic inference in primates in a poster presentation at Indiana University. The PI also taught at workshops on species delimitation and machine learning during the project period.
